entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin momentum movement, particle sufficient to turn the scales, moment, from movēre to move

def.dt: :a minute portion or point of time :instant
:a comparatively brief period of time
:present time
:a time of excellence or conspicuousness
:importance in influence or effect
:a cause or motive of action
:a stage in historical or logical development
:tendency or measure of tendency to produce motion especially about a point or axis
:the product of quantity (as a force) and the distance to a particular axis or point
:the mean of the nth powers of the deviations of the observed values in a set of statistical data from a fixed value
:the expected value of a power of the deviation of a random variable from a fixed value

:a measure of the resistance of a body to angular acceleration about a given axis that is equal to the sum of the products of each element of mass in the body and the square of the element's distance from the axis
:the final sword thrust in a bullfight
:a moment of crisis on whose outcome much or everything depends
:the moment produced by a magnetic or electric dipole
:the product of the distance between the two poles and the magnitude of either pole

:a vector quantity that is a measure of the torque exerted on a magnetic system (as a bar magnet or dipole) when placed in a magnetic field and that for a magnet is the product of the distance between its poles and the strength of either pole
:the occasion when the mental atmosphere is most certain to be favorable to the full effect of an action or event
:an instance of momentary forgetfulness or confusion that is attributed to the aging process
:occurring or developing without premeditation :hastily extemporized a spur–of–the–moment decision

entry.et: Middle English spure, from Old English spura; akin to Old English spurnan to kick spurn

def.dt: :a pointed device secured to a rider's heel and used to urge on the horse
def.set: from the acquisition of spurs by a person achieving knighthood
def.dt: :recognition and reward for achievement won his academic spurs as the holder of a chair in a university James Mountford
:a goad to action :stimulus
:something projecting like or suggesting a spur: as
:a projecting root or branch of a tree, shrub, or vine
:a stiff sharp spine (as on the wings or legs of a bird or insect)
:one on a cock's leg
:a gaff for a gamecock
:a hollow projecting appendage of a corolla or calyx (as in larkspur or columbine)
:a bony outgrowth (as on the heel of the foot)
:climbing iron
:an angular projection, offshoot, or branch extending out beyond or away from a main body or formation
:a ridge or lesser elevation that extends laterally from a mountain or mountain range
:a railroad track that branches off from a main line
:a reinforcing buttress of masonry in a fortification

dro.drp: on the spur of the moment

def.dt: :on impulse :suddenly
